reviewText: There's very little historical information imparted in this conglomeration for bad Italian and Spanish accents, and it presents an inaccurate picture of the roles of King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella. With just a little care, it could have been informative without losing any of the nonsense that gives it "kid appeal".

reviewText: The funny thing is that I didn't realize when I was a kid how crudely some of the characters are drawn, but that downtick does not affect my enjoyment.(I assume the "Wayback Machine" that shows how web pages used to look years ago got its name from Mr. Peabody's invention.)I especially love the puns at the end of each historical vignette, for example,the sea explorer who was first to travel around the world being such a good poker player that he won 265 games in a row, all with the same type of hand. It's in the history books, the STRAIGHTS OF MAGELLAN.or the famous author who got put in jail, he was BARRED IN AVON, but history changed it to BARD OF AVON.I hope when I get done with the BEST OF, that I will find other examples. I'm watching it in small pieces so my enjoyment can stretch.Or maybe I'll have to borrow the Wayback Machine to bring more episodes back from the past.
summary: I am SO SO SO SO enjoying the Wayback Machine
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1

reviewText: I would highly recommend that you go back and watch some of the videos.  Rocky and Bullwinkle was classic and is still very funny today.  Mr. Peabody and Sherman were a very integral part of the long-lasting humor of this program.

reviewText: I remember watching these in reruns as a kid, but I didn't remember the particulars. Watched a few episodes the other night, and oh, man! They are all just strange set-ups for really, really bad puns. Now, I happen to be a fan of really bad puns, so this works for me. The animation is pretty bad, but that's okay, too. What interests me beyond the style of the shorts is that the cultural references that are the bases of the puns are nearly extinct themselves. In fact, I think many of them would be entirely lost on large swaths of the population already. Ah, well. I'm sure they will make all things new with the upcoming feature film, whose very existence is mind boggling to conceive after watching a couple of the original episodes.
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1

reviewText: Kids and adults will love these cartoons. I loved them as a kid but now I can appreciate some of the underlying adult humor. My neices like the funny cartoons and how they go back in time to give history lessons.

reviewText: I have been a huge fan of the Rocky & Bullwinkle Show since my childhood.  I'd be hard pressed to pick a favorite segment but it would probably be Dudley Doright (Nell, Snidely, the Colonel & Horse included) so I'll be at the head of the line for their "Best of" but my next favorite was the Wayback Machine & its crew.  I've been shocked by the trailers at how far the theatrical remake has fallen from Hanna-Barbera standards so I really needed this dose of the real thing.  Very timely!

reviewText: A throwback to the early sixties, with humor that was funny then, but not so funny now. J Wars had an interesting slant on history and current events in all his cartoons. Written for an early-teen Cold War audience. Takes me back to when "funny" was a lot simpler, and no bashing was necessary.
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1

reviewText: Have not seen this show in probably fifty years, when I was a child.  It was nice to see it again.  I don't know if it would please someone who did not grow up with the show but I did enjoy seeing it again.
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1

reviewText: I used to watch this segment of Bullwinkle every time I got a chance when I was a teenager. I guess I'm still a teenager at heart, because I still laughed when I watched it again. I wanted the segments to be longer, but they are short, of course, and they are very, very funny.
summary: The Best of Mr. Peabody and Sherman, Vol. 1
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1

reviewText: After seeing the movie, I thought it would be fun to see the old TV shows I remember as a child.  They are good.  They are educational in that they introduce historical figures, although the twisted nature of the narratives could end up creating more confusion than anything.  Nevertheless, just having your child exposed to the great names of history could be very helpful in making your child history-literate.  If they need to explore more about these figures - there's always Google.
summary: A good, even somewhat educational, series
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1

reviewText: This is such a wacky cartoon, that it's hard not to love. The concept of a genius dog that adopts a boy and travels around time using a machine that he built himself must be drug induced. I learned so much about history as a kid from watching this cartoon, most of it completely fabricated. The plots are ridiculous and the puns atrocious. I highly recommend it!The picture quality is very good and somebody had fun designing the case. One big problem is that the disc came off the spindle during shipping and rattled around inside enough that it badly scuffed the reflective side. Amazon sent me a replacement, but the case on this one doesn't have the same cool die cut window.
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1

reviewerName: Kirk Groeneveld "Star Trek, Sci Fi and Harry ...
reviewText: Before there was Dr. Who, before Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure,  there was the Rocky and Bullwinkle show, with many fast paced fractured tales of history and fairy tales.As a regular staple of cartoon viewing in the early 1960s, Jay Ward's production stood out from the others with quick, sly wit, bad puns and fast pace.This collection is a wonderful example of the style of his animation, starting from the very first Mr. Peabody and Sherman cartoon installment, setting up the series and explainingjust who they are and why they are together.  Bet you never heard that tale, did you?This volume, billed "The BEST of Mr. Peabody and Sherman Volume 1" contains 15 of the roughly five minute features, with luminaries like, Napolean, Cleopatra, Ben Franklin, and others.  The puns come thick and fast, but the last bad pun for the closer is guaranteed to be a groaner.This is a must see for the younger generation, to see what their parents and grandparents grew up on, long before Bart and Homer Simspson tried to corner the market on smart ass comments.A reasonable value on it's own, an extra feature of the Bullwinkle live puppet intros that were featured during the first season are included.Though this DVD doesn't show anything more than the basic Mr. Peabody and Sherman, it is a good item to have or share.  Perhaps another DVD that contains a sample complete show might give more of the overall flavor, but this isn't bad.My kids were appalled, but sat through the entire DVD with mom and dad and we laughed again at the bad puns and simple animation. Don't miss this opportunity to share the laughs.
summary: Go Way Back to the Beginning of Peabody & Sherman
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1

reviewText: These Cartoons are some of the classics, they can't compare to the new digital computer generated cartoons but, if you are of the era that I'm from you know that these cartoons just can't be beat.

reviewText: Mr. Peabody is a TV talisman.  I always walk away from these cartoons feeling magically transformed and energized.In the realm of vintage cartoons made on minimal budgets, Jay Ward rules!  Peabody & Sherman, along with Rocky & Bullwinkle, etc, were very much like sly, fast-talking radio plays staged by smartly stylized cartoon characters.  This DVD also contains rare Bullwinkle puppet segments that were used in the early broadcasts.  They too underline how WAY ahead of the curve Ward was in terms of getting sophisticated and sometimes subversive humor in under the radar.By the way, Peabody's "boy" Sherman was voiced by a man in his 40's named Robert Tetley.  Amazing.
summary: Buy this DVD, even if every fiber in your body says "no"!
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1

reviewText: Oh, those childhood memories.  Those very inaccurate history lessons, very bad puns, and cheezy animation.  No, I'm not talking about "South Park."  I'm referring to those Jay Ward shorts in the Rocky and Bullwinkle Show.  Still, this IS funny stuff.  Well worth owning.  Anyone interested in animation or those wacky 60s and 70s should make this required viewing.  The jokes are a little stale now, but were they ever that fresh anyway.  Who cares!!! It's Mr. Peabody and his boy Sherman.  Sit (way)back and enjoy.
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1

reviewText: Bought for my husband as he used to get a kick out of this when we were first married.  He very much enjoyed it.

reviewText: I recently took my two young grandsons to see the new movie of the same name.  Of course, they never had their dad wake them up in Saturday morning (c.1960) to watch Rocky and Bullwinkle.  Everyone else in our house wanted to sleep in but Dad knew I would be only too glad to drag my blanket and pillow and sit on the floor next to his chair to watch cartoons every Saturday.  Rocky and Bullwinkle were big favorites of his.  Anyway, the series still works and is still fun to watch.  A perfect combination of both silly and sophisticated jokes, with some sweetness thrown in.  Fun for kids and adults alike, at least I hope so.  Today's kids are pretty used to c.g. effects and may find this boring.  They might actually have to pay attention to the dialogue!
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1

reviewText: I've always enjoyed the shows.  It's nice to look back through them.  The humor is just as good now as it was then.

reviewText: Oh, God. I've just let everybody know how old I am! Once upon a time, when the world made sense(at least to me) there was a cartoon called Rockey and Friends, featuring Rocket(hence Rocky) J. Squirrell and his best friend, Bullwinkle T. Moose. They  had an arch enemy named Boris Badenov and his girlfriend, Natasha. You younger pups may have seen an extremely forgettable movie featuring them. It was so bad and forgettable that, thankfully, I forgot the name of the movie. Rocky's friends included Dudley Doright of the Royal Canadian Mounties and his girlfriend Nell, Aesop's fables, Fractured Fairy Tales and our above featured duo, Mr. Peabody & Sherman. Mr. Peabody was obviously a dog, albeit a genius, who had adopted a young boy named Sherman from an orphange. As he put it, "If every boy should have a dog, it was only logical that every dog should have a boy." Mr. Peabody had invented the Wayback Machine which allowed he and Sherman to enter a date, step into the Wayback Machine, and immediately be transported back in time to that date. These trips usually came about because Sherman was a bright and inquisitive boy and wanted to know the story behind whatever had occured on that date. Nine times out of nine, Mr. Peabody had to intervene because somone was about to do something stupid, which would have altered what we now know was the course of history as it was supposed to have happened. At the end of every story, when Mr. Peabody had set the course of history straight, he offered up to Sherman an excellent lesson punctuated by an equally excellent pun. The show was great for many reasons, not the least of which was it taught kids history. The history may have been somewhat skewed in the telling but, in the end, it made history interesting for kids and also taught them the meaning of satire! You'll notice that Amazon also offers all of the affiliated Rocky shows in their catalog. If you enjoy this series, do yourself a favor and look up the Pogo series. Pogo was a possum in the swamps of the Okeefenokee and featured one of the most intriguing set of characters you will ever meet.  There was Howlan Owl, Albert the Alligator, Churchy LaFemme(get it?) the turtle, 'Lil Pup Dog, and many others. The strip was written by Walt Kelly, one of the greatest cartoonists and philosophers who ever lived. He was one of the first major cartoonists to lampoon public politicians, from George Wallace, J. Edgar Hoover, Spiro Agnew, Tricky Dick Nixon, and a host of others. He was fearless in his visual portrayals of them and his unabashed opinion of the cultural times. You will not only enjoy all of the shenanigans of the denizens of the swamp, but it's also a real hoot to try to recognize all the public figures. He took on the KKK, whom he referred to as the Kluck Klams, and no nut fringe group or individual was left unscathed. I know I say it a lot but, THANK YOU AMAZON for making these incredibly historical and important glimpses into another time available to us. I hope you enjoy all of these collections and take great personal pride that you can actually understand the difference between them and the garbage that our children watch today that are passed off as cartoons.I'm sorry, I forgot that what our kids watch today really ARE cartoons aimed at "the great unwashed" who wouldn't be able to comprehend the afore mentioned works of art. I wish I could take credit for the  term "the great unwashed", but I can't remember where I heard it, So instead of suing me for plagerism, take gratification in the fact that I liked it enough to steal it! I'll leave plagerism to a certain current politician(we all KNOW who you are!) At least, he doesn't mangle the language like another of his cohorts, W, did. THANKS- Tim Drain. You're all welcome to email me at william.t.drain@gmail.com if you like. I must caution you that I'm somewhat crazy, but you probably already know that.
Title: The Best of Dudley Do-Right, Vol. 1
